title: Madge's handwritten font
content:
i was perusing the board, saw this [[http://typophile.com/node/15328](http://web.archive.org/web/20081025044141/http:/typophile.com/node/15328 "http://typophile.com/node/15328") ] and had been wondering about this for the last year:

does anybody here know the name of the gorgeous handwritten font used on Madonna’s album and single releases from her “Confession on a Dancefloor” covers?

thanks in advance.  
doc.theopolis

 [‹ French Automobile Newspaper wedge serif face](http://web.archive.org/web/20081025044141/http:/www.typophile.com/node/29620 "Go to previous forum topic") [(x) Nineteenth-century Scottish book of testimonials - various similar {gang} ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20081025044141/http:/www.typophile.com/node/29608 "Go to next forum topic")
author: DocTheop

comments.content: I’d wonder if it wasn’t just the designers handwriting. There isn’t very much consistency.

i figured it could be, but on the off-chance it was a font... i thought i’d ask!  
for some reason i find the thinness really intriguing.

I think Tiffany’s absolutely right that this script is handwriting, but there are some new OpenType handwritten fonts like [Dear Sarah](http://web.archive.org/web/20081025044141/http:/www.veer.com/products/typedetail.aspx?image=UMT0000104) that have many alternate characters, endings and ligatures that allow simulation of rather realistic handwriting.

- Mike Yanega

True, true. Opentype has opened the world up to hand-written simulation.

( Gah! No pun intended. )
yes, but in this case the lettering varies from sample to sample. that’d take more work to make a font than to just write it out in the first place. :P
